clinical_study.brief_title: Cognitive Training With and Without tDCS to Improve Cognition in HIV
clinical_study.official_title: Cognitive Training With and Without tDCS to Improve Cognition in HIV

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to develop pilot data on the potential efficacy of computer-based cognitive training or the combination of computer-based cognitive training with transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) in improving cognitive function in persons with HIV-related mild neurocognitive disorder (MND). tDCS is a noninvasive brain stimulation technique in which a small direct current (1-2 mA) is applied to the scalp during a cognitive or motor activity, inducing a very small current that affects specific neural circuits related to the site at which electrodes are placed. tDCS has been judged safe and has shown significant treatment effects in studies with other populations, but has not been extensively studied in individuals with HIV infection. tDCS has been shown to facilitate learning in a number of studies, suggesting that it may improve or enhance learning in those with cognitive problems. As HIV infection is associated with decrements in a number of cognitive skills, including working memory, executive functions, and psychomotor speed that are related to individuals' functional status and medication adherence, the demonstration of a technique to enhance the effects of cognitive training in this population would have substantial clinical benefits as well as scientific value.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Pilot study protocol terminated to begin expanded study.

primary_outcome.measure: Working memory: Participants' rate of improvement
primary_outcome.description: Participants' rate of improvement on a visual working memory task

secondary_outcome.measure: Center for Epidemiological Studies Depression Scale (CES-D)
secondary_outcome.description: Participants' mood over the course of the study

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 years of age or older
- Fluent in English
- Meets Frascati criteria for mild neurocognitive disorder
Exclusion Criteria:
- Left handed
- Presence of dementia
- Use of specific psychotropic medications including antidepressants, antipsychotics, and sleep-promoting medications
